column2: Building Your Own Adventure!
What you'll do
Saniel teaches you how to create your own file system, Choose-Your-Own-Adventure style!
Greetings, {{user_name}}. So you're back for more, are you? Excellent - I see real potential in you, and I've got just the thing.
Let's launch the Terminal.
Once again, the humble Terminal. Now, you already know that the text on the left is called the prompt, which tells you where you are in the filesystem. Let's type a quick ls to get our bearings.
There's your home directory, well done. You've done solid work learning to navigate the existing filesystem, but did you know you can also create your own filesystem?
The filesystem is just a collection of files and folders. If you know how to use nano to create files, the last piece you're missing is how to create folders, which are also often called directories.

I mention that last part again, because the command is called mkdir - Make Directory. I confess I'm surprised the original system designers bothered to make it more than 2 letters long - it feels positively luxurious!
Now, let's give that a try - We're going on an adventure today, so let's make a directory called Adventure - type mkdir Adventure
Well done! If you type ls again, you can see that there is a new entry called Adventure. To confirm that it is indeed a directory, see if we can cd into it. Do you remember how?
That's right - it's cd Adventure. Let's go inside.
Now, if you look at the prompt, you will see that we are indeed inside Adventure. If you're like me, you might have already typed ls out of habit to see what's inside this directory.
There's nothing inside, of course, since we just created it. Let's put something inside, though, a text file named README. Do you remember how to create a text file?

Right - nano README. This file, when read, will welcome your user to the adventure you are about to create. A quick note on filenames: Be careful to never use spaces in filenames! Programs interpret them in unpredictable ways. So, in the interests of safety, use - (dash) or _ (underscore) if you need to simulate a space.

Did you ever read one of those stories where you can choose your own path, and you had to flip back and forth between pages? Well, that's the type of thing we're going to create, today. For now, let's put a greeting in here, maybe "Welcome to my adventure!". You can come up with a more detailed introduction later, if you want.
Remember to save the file (Ctrl+O) before you try to exit (Ctrl+X). Hit Enter when you see the file name pop up at the bottom, and then you can exit.
Let's make sure that worked - type cat README to see what the file says.
Excellent. Now let's make another file called castle - type nano castle

Let's make this file about entering the castlle, type something about a drawbridge or a massive door. Maybe "Welcome to the castle! The drawbridge lowers as you approach, and you walk hesitantly inside."
Make sure to save (Ctrl+O) and exit (Ctrl+X) when you're done.
Now type ls - you should see both README and castle in your Adventure directory.
Oh, wait, fiddlesticks. That's supposed to be a directory named castle, not a file. We can't have the player "go inside" the castle unless it's a directory!
Well, this is a good opportunity to learn how to delete files, I suppose. No two files can have the same name, so we need to delete this one.

I'm sure you have deleted files before using a graphical interface before - just press Delete and the file goes into the "trash bin". Well, the command-line is different. There's no safety net here, if you delete something - ZAP. Nevertheless, I think it's time that you were given this power. Everyone needs to shoulder this responsibility eventually.

To delete a file, we use the command rm. Used carelessly, this command has been known to trash entire filesystems, so always think very hard before you type it. In our case, here, we know exactly what we want to get rid of, so please type rm castle.
Good work. You might have guessed that rm stands for remove, and if you type ls into the command line, you will see that the file has indeed been removed!

Using rm on individual files is quite safe, as long as you are very sure of what's in those files. It's when you start trying to delete multiple files that people get into terrible, terrible situations.
Ahem, that's enough of my dire warnings, I think. Back to our adventure! We were going to make a directory called castle...
So, let's mkdir castle and then cd castle so we can continue.
Now that we're inside castle, we can make another README file (or whatever you'd like to call it) that welcomes the user to the castle - so, nano README
Back to what we typed before in that deleted file - "Welcome to the castle! The drawbridge lowers as you approach, and you walk hesitantly inside. There are two doors in front of you."
This is where things get interesting. Let's give the player a choice of where to go next, like creating several doors leading out of a room. Any ideas on how to do that?
You might have guessed that we'll do it through 2 more directories - Type mkdir Door1 and then mkdir Door2
Now when the user types ls they will see two new directories, and they will have to choose which to go into. Let's cd Door1 and make something interesting behind it.
This is where you get to drive the adventure - what do you think is behind Door 1? Use nano to create a README file, and then write up a description of what's in this room.

Excellent! Now that we have Door 1's README, let's go back up to the castle directory and go into Door2. You have been taught how to go back up a directory, correct? Let's have a quick referesher, just in case.

To go "up" in the filesystem, you'll need to use the universal command cd .. - That's cd (space) period period. This command will always take you to the "parent" directory of the one you're in. For Door1, that's castle. Let's go back to castle now.
There you go! We're back in the castle - you can check the prompt and use ls just to make sure. Now let's cd Door2 so we can build out more of our adventure.
Behind Door 2, begin by creating a README file that explains what the user sees. This time, let's have the adventure continue - maybe the user can either turn "Right" or "Left"?
After you create the README file, create the new directories (using mkdir) that the user will navigate into next.
From here on, the adventure is yours to create! Is your castle magical? Haunted? An elaborate hologram? A complete virtual reality? The only limit is your imagination.
I've got a few tips to help you along:
1) Remember that you can use "cd .." to travel back up one directory.

2) If you make a mistake, you can use "rm." If you need to remove a directory, you will need type rm -r DirectoryName, using the actual name of the directory. Be careful, though. Once it's rmed, that's the end of it.

3) It might be helpful to plan out your filesystem by drawing a map. Write "Adventure" at the top of your page, and then draw a line down to the word "castle". From there, you can draw two lines branching down - one to "Door1" and the other to "Door2", etc.
That's all for now, I'll let you loose to craft your masterpiece. You're quite a talented student, and I'm looking forward to playing your adventure. I'm sure your friends are as well!
